div.p: The complete absence of enthusiasm is the most striking feature of the Russian press comments regarding the Assembly project. There are no signs of rejoicing anywhere. The high rental qualification of the town voters excludes the majority of the educated classes. Only 5,000 inhabitants in St Petersburg are qualified. Rioting took place at Kichineff following the publication of the project Several thou- sand demonstrators were dispersed by the mounted police. (Reuter)
The Tsar’s manifesto has been greeted with indifference. (Havas)

According to a telegram received yesterday evening from Portsmouth (N.H.), the "Times” learns that the Tsar held a Council at which it was finally decided that no further concessions can be made. (Reuter)

Warsaw, August 21. A general strike has been proclaimed here owing to the indignation caused by the pro- cedure in connection with the elections, which will treat the Poles in a similar manner to the Asiatic nomade. (Reuter)
A general strike at Warsaw and Lodz is reported. (Havas)
Professor Milioskow and ten other well- known liberals have been arrested. (Havas)
(Official). Lord Minto will sucoeed Visoount Curzon. (Reuter)

The new Vioeroy of India is son of the third Earl of Minto. Born on July 9,1847, he was educated at Eton and Trinity College, Cam- bridge. An ensign in the Scots Guards in 1867, he saw active service with the Turkish Army in 1877, and in the second Afghan war in 1879. He acted as private secretary to Lord Roberts during the latter’s brief visit to the Cape in 1881, volunteered for the Egyptian campaign in 1885, and was military secretary to the Marquis of Lansdowne while the present Foreign Minister was Governor General of Canada in 1883-85. In 1885 he was chief of the staff during the hard fought little campaign against the rebellious Indians and half-breds in the north-west of the Dominion. He con- tested Hexham in 1886, and in 1891 succeeded to the title. He was created G.C.M.G. in 1898, in which year he was appointed Governor- General of Canada, a post which he filled with consistent sucoess till 1904, when he was suc- ceeded by Earl Grey. Lord Minto married, in 1885, Mary, daughter of General the Hon. Charles Grey.
It is notified that the Army Council does not intend to carry out any further reduction of the British garrison in Egypt. (Reuter)
Owing to the rising in East Africa, the Government is despatching 160 marines, to- gether with machine guns and two small cruisers. (Reuter)
Owing to rigorous preventive measures, the yellow fever is abating. (Reuter)
Quarantine — Arrivals from Adalia are now subjected to a medical visit only.
Greek Philharmonic Society.—A concert will be given by this society to-morrow evening, commencing at 9 p.m.
Delta Barrage —A building for models is to be constructed at the Delta Barrage in the near future.
The Post Office at Sennar is now op- ened to foreign ordinary, inland ordinary, and telegraphic money service.
Commercial Treaties.—It is hoped that the commercial treaty between Egypt and Italy will be signed in November.
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Imam distriot of Cairo during to-morrow night and at dawn of the 23rd inst. will be poisoned by the police.
The Plague.—Yesterday’s plague bulletin reoords one now admission to hospital at Port Baid, and the recovery of the solitary case at

Suez Canal.— 16 vessels passed through the Canal on the 18th inst., 11 of whioh wereBritish, 1 German, 2 French, 1 Turkish, 1 Austrian. The day's reoeipts were frs. 424,603.23 making the total from the 1st inst frs. 5,580,764.21.

Injured by a Buffalo.—A startled buffalo cow ran down a man and woman on Sonday in Moharrem Bey quarter. The woman was severely injured and requires fifteen days treatment The man came cff comparatively lightly.

A Brutal Husband.—On Sunday a certain Hassan Aisa Ali hurled a lighted lamp at his wife Zanouba, who had asked him for some money for household expenses, irflicting serious burns on the poor woman, who has bad to be removed to hospital.

Killed by Scorpions.—Two more deaths from the stings of scorpions are reported from Cairo, a child having died from this cause in the Darb el Ahmar quarter, and another in Old Cairo, where such fatalities have been comparatively common of late.

Injured at Play.—A lad' named Ismail Abd el Moneim, 11 years of age, was flying his kite from the roof of a house at El Halwagi, near the Customs, on Sunday, when he made a false step, and fell into the attest, sustaining injuries that necessitate ten days’ medical treatment.

Attempted Murder.—A Cairene butcher named Ahmed el Habashi recently quarrelled in the course of an argument with Hafzallah Mankarius and stabbed him in the abdomen. The polioe of the Khalifa kism have sinoe arrested the would-be murderer, whose victim has been taken to hospital.

The Sarkis Affair.—We are glad to hear that the Armenian community of Alexandria has decided to send the two yoonggirls concern- ed in this painful affair to an Armenian oonvent for orphans at Constantinople. The "decision does great credit to the humanity andoommon sense of our Armenian fellow oitizens.

The Alhambra Theatre.—To-morrow night the Della Guardia Dramatic Company will present Le Pillole cCErcole at this theatre. Lorde'a drama La Dormiente will be given very shortly and the oompany also bills Pam- ela Marchande de Frivolitfi to appear soon. Subscription tiokets may be obtained at the box-office of the theatre.

Hashish Seizures.—Six turbos of hashish were found in a sack of flower by the Customs authorities yesterday, whilst on Saturday two women named Luisa Moretti and Elena Cassa- pido while returning from the 8.8. Imperator Nioolai were arrested by the quay polioe. The female searcher emp'oyed discovered eight turbas of hashish oonoealed in their skirts.

Tne Liege Exhibition.—Among the mem- bers of the Jury of the International Exhibition at liege we notioe the name of Mr. Collonge, director general of Berlitz Sohools. This official nomination is still another homage rendered to a celebrated institution, and to a system whioh has rendered possible such progress in the study of modem languages. 26347-1

British Chamber of Commerce.—We would draw the attention of manufacturers and mer- chants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Bgypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole object of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appoint- ing suitable agents. As no fee is oharged for I such advice, it is obviously in the interests of j all British traders here to beoome members, especially when it is remembered that the annual subecription is merely the nominal one • £1. The latter payment also includes a oopy | of the monthly Journal issued by the Chamber j Home enquirers oan obtain farther particulars from oar London offioe, 86, New Broad-street which acts as agents to the Chamber.

Invitations will be issued this week by the Cabinet of the Grand Master of Ceremonies for the banquet whioh will be given by the Acting Regent at Ras el Tin Palace on Sep- tember 1st Among the guests will be the ministers, advisers and under-secretaries of state, the Diplomatic Agents of the Domains Administration, and the Caisse de la Dette, the State Railways and other Administrations, General Bullock, the Acting Governor of Alexandria, and the Consuls of the Powers at Alexandria.

In his report on the reoent action at Sebk-el- Hamis, Marshal Ahmed Faizi Pasha, Com- mander of the Ottoman forces in the Yemen, states that the action lasted from 8 a.m. to midday, and that the retreating rebels left many dead behind them. Tarkish authority is re-established at Menakhkha.

Thif bulletin issued by the Ministry of the Interior for the week ending last Saturday again shows a very considerable decrease in the area of land in whioh the ootton-worm still exists. The following are the reports from the four affected provinces. Gharbieh :—825 fed dans, belonging to 68 proprietors, have been affested by the worm, and 811 of these have been cleared by 718 ohildren. Behera :—2,396 feddans, belonging to 48 proprietors, have been affected, and 2,804 have been cleared by 6,641 children. Dakahlieh :—109 feddans, belonging to 45 proprietors, have been affected, and 102 cleared by 810 children. Damietta :—9} feddans, belonging to 9 proprietors, have been affected, and have all been cleared by 61 children. Comparing the above with the report of last week, we find that the number of affeoted provinces is roduoed by one, Kalionbieh being nowontire'y free from the worm.In theGharbieh province tho number of affeoted feddans shows a decrease of 814, in Dakahlieh a decrease of 13, in Damietta a decrease of 11}, and in Behora an inorease of 1,141 feddans. The ii orease in the number of feddans attacked in the Behera provinoe must in no way be taken to indicate a general increase, for it must be remembered that this provinoe has suffered much more severely, not only during the present year,but also in former ones, than any other, and in the reports ofeaoh week we have noted a considerable numerical difference between the areas attacked and those cleared. It is obvious that the insect is much more strongly established in this province than in any other. Those who know the Prodenia littoralit find it one of tho commonest of the moths whioh fly round lamps or eleotrio lights at night in Alexandria and the neighbourhood.

Leave of absence has been granted to the following officials of the Sudan Government and Army Officers until the undermentioned dates :— El Kaimakam Carter Bey, officer command- ing 9th Sudanese, until 29th September ; El g.;m»Viun Cameron Bey, senior inspector of the Sennar provinoe until 1st October; El Bimbashi Arden, 4th battalion, until 29th September ; El Bimbashi Elderton, deputy assistant financial recretary until 15th Septem- ber ; El Bimbashi Mayne, D.S.O.. 18th Sudan- eie, until 2nd October; El Bimbashi Cox, 3rd battalion, until 2nd Ootober ; El Bim- bashi Rawson, 15th Sudanese, until 29th October. Leave in extension has been granted to El Kaimakam Garsia Bey, D.S.O., department of supplies, until 20th September ; to El Bimbashi Dale, deputy assistant director of posts and telegraphs, until 29th October ; and to El Bimbashi Heath, Camel Corps, until 4th Ootober.

Dissensions and disputes having arisen of late between the heirs to the immense properties left by Ahmed Menshawi Pasha, the wealthy landed proprietor who died suddenly in Cairo some months ago, three native nota- bles have been appointed arbitrators by the Meglis El Haaby.They are Ismail Pasha Abaza, Hassan Pasha Rassim and Saad Bey Zsglool. The heirs are the lady Fatma Amen,the widow, daughter of the late Abdalla Pasha Inglisi, an Englishman, a daughter, and two sons, one of whom is at Tourah serving a long term of imprisonment on a charge of murder. The late Menshawi Pasha left properties whioh give, it is reported, an annual income of £40,000 at least, but a portion of his large estates were handed over to the Wekfs for the benefit of the poor and certain mosques. Itisoertain clauses in his will that have been the oause of the dissensions between the members of his family, who are seeking to set aside some of them. The son, who is now in prison was, it appeals, disinherited, and he is also disputing the will, but it is hoped and expeoted that the arbitrators reoently named will be able to settle the difference that have arisen and satisfy all the interested parties.

Monday’s 'Official Journal' oontains the text of the oonoession granted to the Cairo Tram- ways Company by the Egyptian Government We have already described the routes to be followed by the new lines, and will oonfine ourselves to mentioning the principal condi- tions imposed by the Government whioh are of considerable interest The Tramways Company undertakes to use ao rails in the future but those of the •Ph«nix’ type of 68 kilogrammes per metre, and to replace the rails at present in use by the above mentioned type by Deoember 81,1990, at latest The Pyramids Une,however, will form an exoeption to this rule, for the rails of the "Vignol” type will be retained in use between Kasrel Nil and Mena House. Of the tramways the Saptieh and Shoubra lines are to be completed and working within two Cof the signature of the oonoession (i.e. July 18, 1906), the Sahel (Rod el Fang) line within five yean, and the Ghamrah and Abattoirs lines within one year from the abora date. The doubling of the old Cairo line is to be completed by the end of this month, greatly to the relief, we imagine, of all who live near the Kasr el Aini Road. The line from Foum el Khalig to the Southern bridge over the small branch of the Nile will be constructed oonourrently with the widening of the road by the Tan rim. The Ghizeh line across Rodah Island and the new bridges will be completed as soon as the bridges are open to heavy traffic, and the Imam-el-Shaffdi line is to be completed within fifteen yean from the 18th ult. The minimum radius of all ourves is fixed at 25 metres, exospt in special cases which the Ministry of Publio Works will determine. The speed of the trams is not to exceed twelve kilometres an hour and must be reduced at all points where the Ministry of Publio Works oonsiden a lower speed neoessary in the interests of publio safety. The new and the previous oonoessions expire simultaneously, viz. on Deoember 6, 1951, when the whole of the properties of the Tramways Company will fall to the Government

There -have been persistent rumours for some time in Cairo that the Mena House Hotel and the surrounding property of some 100 feddans, belonging to Mrs. Locke-King, widow of the late owner, had been acquired by, or were under option to, the Nnngovioh Hotels Company, but we are informed that snob is not the fact The foots of the oase are that an offer of pur- chase for £>20,000 was reoently made by the representatives of an English syndicate to the lady’s agent, bat was refuted, and sinoe then it was pffered to the above oompany at a slightly higher prioe, whioh offer was not, bow- The original hotel bnildings and the different additions and improvements made sinoe have, it is said, cost from first to last £80,000. The hotel is held by Mr. E. Weokel, the present proprietor manager, on a ten yean’ lease, of which about seven years are expired, at an annoal rental of £4,000. There is no like- lihood of there being any immediate ohange, however, in the ownership of the property, as Mr. Weokel, who is now at Luoerne, has just sent out orders for all the repairs neoessary for the reopening of the hotel on the 1st November to be proceeded with at once.

The Survey Department has issued through the Preea Bureau in Cairo the following in- teresting particulars regarding the ooming eclipse of the sun. The oentral line of the total eclipse of August 80 will pass near the railway station of Kbat- tara, about 12 kilometres north of Assouan ; the phenomena will be visible as a total eolipee from near Bdfn to near the village of Dakka, aouth of Assouan ; north and south of this area the eolipee will be partial, and at Cairo about nine-tenths of the enn’s disc will be oovered. The eolipee will oommenoe in Cairo at fonr minutes past three, at thirteen minutes past four it will have reaohed its middle, and the end will be at fifteen minutes past five. The time will not differ greatly in the Nila Valley localities.

After several postponements occasioned by delay in the completion of the premises, the oentral Government telegraph offioe in Cairo is to be transferred on the 1st September to the new bnildings in the 8haria Boulak belonging to the Daira Khasea, whioh have been taken on a ten yean’ lrase at a rental of LE. 500 per annum. The new offices will oooupy part of the ground floor and are an immense improvement on the old ones, whioh had become much too small for the great inorease of bosioess especially sinoe the open- ing of the Cairo bonne two years ago.

Whenever boe turns to the “Official Gazette" for information ra tenders, sales of public laud etc. etc., the formula-tenders must be sub- mitted on stamped paper* appears in every notice. Under these dreams tonoee it —»m« to unobtainable at the Gonvernorat of Alexandria except in quantities of 1,000 or more sheets at a time. For smaller quantities the buyer mast go to the Post Offioe, or to a small shop in the Tarkish market quite half-an-honr's walk from the Gonvernorat We oannot help thinking that the oonvenienoe of the publio would be better served, if the indispensible sheets of “papier timbed" were procurable at the Gonvernorat. Alexandria, be it remembered, is a town of long distances, and the foot that stamped paper is obtainable in the Souk-el-Turki and at the Post Offioe is not very comforting to persons who are equidistant from both these places, and, when applying to the Gouvernorat, are informed that,their needs cannot be served unless they oare to take a thousand sheets, —more than enough to last the ordinary man for a lifetime.

(From our Correspondent.) Suez, Monday. The cargo of the S.S. Gibraltar whioh was on fire at Suez lest Thursday afternoon, suddenly took fire again on Saturday after noon, and again yesterday. Thanks to prompt assistance, the fire was soon extinguished by flooding the bold, and the vessel is now discharging the damaged oargo in lighten, in order to avoid similar probable outbreaks.

Messrs. Archibald M’Millan and Son, limit- ed, shipbuilders, Dumbarton, laanohed on the 8th inst the steel screw steamer Menepthah, whioh they have built to the order of the Moss Steamship Co., Liverpool (Messrs. James Moss and Co.) for their Mediterranean trade. The vessel, whioh has been built to Lloyd’s highest class, is of the following dimensions Length 315 feet, breadth 44 feet 6 inches, depth moulded 25 feet 5 inches, and is fitted with all the latest improvements for the rapid and efficient working of cargo. Large and airy state rooms have been fitted amidships for the accommodation of first-class passengers, for whom also is provided cm the bridge deck a handsomely fitted entranoe hall louDge, and smokeroom. Over these is fitted a large pro- menade deck, on whioh is plaoed the captain’s accommodation and chart-room. The aeoond- olass passengers are aooommodated aft in the poop, and the offioen and engineers’ rooms are fitted under the bridge deck The vessel is lighted by electricity throughout, and ample refrigerating chambers have been fitted for the preservation of provisions. The machinery is of the triplo-explanaion type. The vessel and machinery have been superintended during construction by Messrs. William Bsplen and Son, Liverpool, and the christening oeremony was performed by Miss Harding, of Stanton, Bebington, Cheshire.

Hie Moss liner Nitocris arrived yesterday morning from Glasgow with passengers, mails and general cargo. The Khedivial Mail Steamship Assouan will leave Alexandria at 4 p.m. on Saturday and Port Said at 4 p.m. on Sunday for Beyrouth, Tripoli, Mersina, Alexandre tta, Larnaoa, Li- massol, Cai'ffa and Jaffa.

Le pequebot-poste Congo, des Messageries Mari times anrivf aojourd’hui de Marseille avait k bord:— M. R G. 0. Moss, M. K. Fuller, M. Bartlett, M. Eynard, M. et Mme Barker, M. et Mme Mirles, M. Tilhard, Tissot, Verny, 7 Frtres des Booles Chritiennee, Dr. Elis Grad, M. et Mme Por- gnary, M. W. Bonis, Mile Piauoe, M. Moham- med el Dil, M. G. Salibi, M. Piorananti Chinery, M. Q. Roffield, Mme Faro et enfant, M. Marini, M. de Koningh, Mile Cl. Verneuil, Mme Chariton, fomille Nuquimoti, et 89 pas- tagera de 3me et 4me olasses. Lea pa wagers su:vanta sont arrives oe matin par le paquebot Khedivial ‘ Priuoe Abbas” de Constantinople, Dardanelles, Mlielin, Smyrna et Pirde. M.M. Pains, & Cololthis, B. Coidonis, Hassan Abdon GhaH et fils, G. Kyriaooponlos, Ahmed effendi Selim, A. Pavre, Ahmed Bey Assaad, A. Nathan et oompegnon, A.R. Robin sou, Abdul Weteh Bff, Ali Eff. Kamel, P. Stavridis, M. et Mme A. Misnhi et fomille, D. a OylerfD. Pardo, M. Millet, D. Valentis, A. Vafiadia, N. Candopoulos, D.P.T. Kitroeff, J. Coyopoulos, A. Trevlos, B. Calpoyannia, M. Hafiz. 0. Poppa, Panageta, B. Antomopou- loa. N. Mereati, Mme. Dr. Is* Pacha, Finney, Tennant, Yamaha et femffle, Kirakoff, & La- banahkra et so fills, ainsi que 162 t-ffn da port.
Sir Francis O’Calteghan, who, after leaf railway eervioe in indie, beoame merging director of the Uganda Railway, it oomi^ oat in Ootober to Cairo on hie way to Uganda.
Lieutenant W. F. Johnson, Army Service Corpe, has beeo grouted leave of absence until January 4, 1906.

We regret to team that Mr. Wallioh, lame- tor General of the Governmwt Telegraph Department, who left Cairo on tho 15th July on nek leave, haa not benefited by his stay at the bathe of Salsomeggiore in Italy.
We regret to announoe the death, whioh occurred on Saturday at Cairo, of V-i—v— Khalaf Bey Khairy, aide-decamp to the Khedive.
Bimbashi Mohamed Amin, commandant of Police of Keneh district, has been granted leave for two months from 1st proximo.
The handicap for tomorrow’s race will be the same as test week. Class I. Course P. Class IL Coarse Q.
We are asked to remind members that then will be a practice on Saturday next at Mostepha range, omnmanning at 8 p.m.
We do not hold ourselves responisble for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discounts.

To the Editor of the Egyptian Gaxhte. Sir,—I was glad to read in a reoent Dumber of your esteemed journal that the little Anglican Church, at Niooaia, Cyprus, haa been greatly improved, as regards deoorations. It is a nioe little church and what puzzles me, is why no steps have ever been tafan to organise a proper choir. Probably they have one by now, but when I was these last-nr no snoh thing existed. On my enquiring why they did not have one, I was told that then were not enough people, or some such excuse. Surely there must be four gentlemen and four or five ladies in Niooaia who oan zing 1 If they were to pnetioe onoe a week, as is ifong at the English Churoh here, I believe they would be able to oonduot the servioe chorally, whioh is always nioe, and I am sore the dwp- lain would prefer it Very often the choir at St. Mark’s only numbers about six pessons, and yet they are able to oonduot tho servioe very well I do not therefore see why no steps should be taken to furnish the ohurok at Nioosia with a choir. The late Ven. Archdaaoon 8penoer, very often mentioned that it was a pity no ohoir existed—only it seems he did not try to get one np. The climate is very healthy, and I am surprised to find snoh a comparatively small British oommunity. I am told that nothing goes ahead in Cyprus, and that all who have from time to time establish- ed businesses there had to sell np and leave. I am always interested in anything that deals with Cyprus. 1 am, Sir, etc, A Well-Wisher of Cyprus. Alexandria, August 16.

Te the Editor of the Egyptian Qaam. Sir,—As there may be soma holders of Credit Foncier Egyptian thane here whom it interests, I would oall attention to a very oariont feature in the quotations of their shares reoently issued in Paris. There appears to be an attempt to lower their prioe until after the new issue. Within the test ten days Paris quotation was frs. 815. An order sent to eight brokers in Paris to buy at 8l8gaveno execution, but the prioe row to 822, than on no order being sent prioe was redwood to 816. An order was sent to bay at 819, and a few shares wertf given and prioe was raised to 821, again no order was sent and prioe went np to 816, orders sent at 818 but no shares sold, and we dose at 891. A Haves rumour rays a great financier is striving to make the Credit Fonder shareholders abstain from tbs new issue, ao that the Daira 8anieh shareholders may get a big interest in the Credit Fonder, and thow who had Daira interest may retain an interest in Egyptian affaire, instead being paid off in otah. Henoe this oonstant marking down of prioes without sales. Perhaps this note may save a Credit Fonder shareholder. I ass, Sir, etc., Lux. Alexandria, August 22.
